metadata.case_name: Navaratna Kalpa Pharmacy v. Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories

facts.text: Respondent firm founded in 1926 by Dr. Sarvothama Rao at Ernakulam as Navaratna Pharmacy, name changed to Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories from January 1945, manufactures medicinal products using Trade Mark Navaratna from beginning.
In December 1928, word Navaratna and Navaratna Pharmacy registered by declaration before Registrar of Assurances, Calcutta.
Respondent registered Navaratna as Trade Mark on January 31, 1947 under Cochin Trade Marks Act 19 of 1119 (1944), and Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories on February 17, 1948.
Respondent has expanding business selling products under Navaratna and other marks continuously.
Under Trade Marks Amendment Act 1946 (s.82-A) and Cochin Act (s.78-A), respondent registered Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories in Bombay Trade Marks Registry without opposition.
Appellant carrying on business in Ayurvedic products at Jullundur as Navaratna Kalpa Pharmacy, vending under Navaratna Kalpa.
Appellant applied for registration of Navaratna Kalpa in October 1946, advertised April 1950, opposed by respondent on grounds descriptive and non-distinctive, registration refused.
Appellant applied to Registrar to remove respondent's marks Navaratna and Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories.
Respondent filed O.S. No. 233 of 1951 before District Judge Anjikaimal for permanent injunction against appellant using Navaratna or similar.
Registrar refused rectification due to pendency of suit, directed appellant to High Court.
Appellant filed O.P. No. 19 of 1952 in Kerala High Court (Travancore-Cochin) for removal of respondent's marks from register under s.46.

District Judge held: no passing off due to packing/get-up; Navaratna common in Ayurvedic, no exclusive right; but Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories validly registered with acquired distinctiveness pre-1937, granted injunction limited to full mark.
High Court (judgment November 30, 1960) affirmed District Judge in A.S. No. 233/1959 and O.P. No. 19/1952.
Navaratna etymologically means Ayurvedic preparations of particular composition, used by several firms.
Evidence of respondent's long use of Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories or variants pre-February 25, 1937, acquired factual distinctiveness, no other use by others.

legal_issues.text: Whether Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories is validly registrable under s.6 of Trade Marks Act 1940, despite Navaratna being descriptive, due to proviso to s.6(3) for old marks with acquired distinctiveness.
Whether appellant's mark Navaratna Kalpa / Navaratna Kalpa Pharmacy / Navaratna Pharmacy infringes respondent's registered mark under s.21 as deceptively similar.
Distinction between passing off and infringement of registered trade mark.

petitioner_arguments.text: Navaratna descriptive/common word for Ayurvedic preparations, no exclusive right even with user; Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories not registrable as Pharmaceutical/Laboratories are descriptive, incapable of distinctiveness per s.6(1)(d).
Proviso to s.6(3) does not apply to inherently non-distinctive/descriptive marks; distinctiveness means inherent per s.6(2)/(3), acquired distinctiveness insufficient if prohibited by s.6(1)(d).
Appellant's marks not identical/deceptively similar; no infringement; packing/get-up distinguishes, negates passing off and infringement.
Respondent should disclaim exclusive right to Navaratna per s.13.

respondent_arguments.text: Exclusive right to Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories as registered proprietor; appellant's use infringes and passes off.
Opposed appellant's registration of Navaratna Kalpa as descriptive/non-distinctive.

court_reasoning.text: Navaratna descriptive but full mark Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories acquired distinctiveness by long user pre-1937; proviso to s.6(3) allows registration notwithstanding lack of adaptation to distinguish under s.6(1), if factual distinctiveness proven.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proviso lifts ban under s.6(1)(d) for old marks with acquired distinctiveness; concurrent findings of fact binding.

court_reasoning.text: Proviso not otiose; applies even to descriptive marks if continuously used pre-1937 with additions not substantially affecting identity, evidence of acquired distinctiveness accepted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Navaratna Pharmacy to Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories variant qualifies.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant's Navaratna Pharmacy deceptively similar to respondent's full mark; compare as wholes, including common Navaratna; concurrent findings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No disclaimer ordered below, not entertainable now.

court_reasoning.text: Passing off requires get-up/packing to deceive; infringement under s.21 statutory right, similarity of marks sufficient if likely to deceive, get-up secondary.

holdings.text: Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories validly registered under proviso to s.6(3) Trade Marks Act 1940 due to pre-1937 use and acquired distinctiveness.
Appellant's use of Navaratna Pharmacy/Navaratna Kalpa infringes respondent's mark as deceptively similar under s.21.
Action for infringement distinct from passing off; statutory right prevails on mark similarity.

precedents_cited.relevance: Descriptive words cannot be appropriated as private property.

precedents_cited.case_name: In the matter of American Screw Co.'s appln.
precedents_cited.relevance: Torq-set: direct reference to normal description.

precedents_cited.case_name: Yorkshire Copper Works Ltd. v. Registrar of Trade Marks
precedents_cited.relevance: Geographical name not registrable despite 100% distinctiveness if inherently incapable.

precedents_cited.case_name: In the matter of India Electric Works Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: India for fans: failed on factual distinctiveness, not inherent prohibition.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Rekhpal v. Amrit Dhara Pharmacy
precedents_cited.relevance: Old marks qualify under proviso even if within s.6(1)(d) with factual distinctiveness.

statutes_cited.name: Trade Marks Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Registrability requires distinctiveness; proviso allows old marks with acquired distinctiveness; infringement if deceptively similar.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed both appeals, upheld High Court and District Court: respondent's mark Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories validly registered with injunction against appellant's infringing use; no interference with concurrent findings.
outcome.relief_granted: Perpetual injunction confined to Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories upheld.

key_quotes.text: "the more apt a word is to describe the goods of a manufacturer, the less apt it is to distinguish them"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why descriptive words inherently lack distinctiveness (citing Lord Simonds).

key_quotes.text: "a passing off by a person of his own goods as those of another, that is not the gist of an action for infringement."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the proviso adds nothing to the section and makes no variation in the law as regards old marks"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects narrow construction rendering proviso otiose.
